Package lexa.core.expression

Provides the classes for expression evaluation.

    Divide the results of two expressions.

    Represent an expression as a single element

Package lexa.core.expression Description

Provides the classes for expression evaluation.

Expressions are built using the Expression.parse function that takes a String and converts it to a block of expressions. When evaluating an expression, an optional DataSet is used to provide the data for any calculations.

An example usage of the parser would be: 

 Expression ex = Expression.parse("id >= 20 && id <= 30"); // get id's between 20 and 30 inclusive.
 DataSet data = new DataSet();
 data.put("id", 33);
 system.out.println(ex.evaluate(data)); // returns false

Expressions strings describe the expression to be built. As the expression is parameterised with a DataSet it can be used multiple times and provide different results depending on the input data.

The format for a valid expression is: 

 EXPRESSION     ::= EXPRESSION ";" EXPRESSION
                  | ID "=" PRIMARY
                  | LOGICAL_OR
 LOGICAL_OR     ::= LOGICAL_AND "||" LOGICAL_OR
                  | LOGICAL_AND
 LOGICAL_AND    ::= COMPARE "&&" LOGICAL_AND
                  | COMPARE
 COMPARE        ::= SUM "<" SUM
                  | SUM "<=" SUM
                  | SUM "==" SUM
                  | SUM "!=" SUM
                  | SUM ">=" SUM
                  | SUM ">" SUM
                  | SUM
 SUM            ::= TERM "+" SUM
                  | TERM "-" SUM
                  | TERM
 TERM           ::= FACTOR "*" TERM
                  | FACTOR "/" TERM
                  | FACTOR
 FACTOR         ::= CONDITION "^" FACTOR
                  | CONDITION "%" FACTOR
                  | CONDITION
 CONDITION      ::= PRIMARY "?" PRIMARY ":" PRIMARY
                  | PRIMARY
 PRIMARY        ::= "-" ELEMENT
                  | "!" ELEMENT
                  | "@" ELEMENT
                  | ELEMENT
 ELEMENT        ::= ID
                  | CONSTANT
                  | "(" EXPRESSION ")"
                  | "[" FUNCTION "]"
 FUNCTION       ::= ID
                  | ID ARGUMENTS
 ARGUMENTS      ::= PRIMARY
                  | PRIMARY ARGUMENTS

Expressions can be concatenated together to produce a script. Each expression is evaluated in order as long as the results are not null. The result of the last expression evaluated is then returned.
